questions.question: What would happen to Earth's atmosphere if gravity were weaker?
options: The atmosphere would be much thinner.
The atmosphere would be much thicker.
The atmosphere would stay the same.
It would float away into space.

questions.question: What is the primary reason that the Earth’s core is so hot?
options: Heat generated by radioactive decay.
The Earth absorbs heat from the Sun.
Heat from ancient impacts during the Earth’s formation.
The Earth is closer to the Sun than other planets.

questions.question: What is the effect of increasing the frequency of a wave?
options: The wavelength increases.
The wavelength decreases.
The wave speed decreases.
The amplitude decreases.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the concept of inertia?
options: An object at rest will stay at rest until acted upon by an external force.
An object will move at a constant speed in a straight line unless acted upon by a force.
An object will only move if pushed.
An object’s velocity depends on the amount of force applied.

questions.question: Why does a person feel weightless in orbit?
options: They are far away from Earth's gravitational field.
They are in free fall, falling toward the Earth but constantly missing it.
There is no gravity in orbit.
The spacecraft cancels out gravity.

questions.question: How does an increase in temperature affect the resistance of a metal conductor?
options: Resistance decreases because the atoms vibrate less.
Resistance increases because the atoms vibrate more.
Resistance remains constant.
Resistance becomes zero.

questions.question: Why does the Moon not have an atmosphere like Earth?
options: The Moon’s gravity is too weak to hold an atmosphere.
The Moon is too cold for an atmosphere to form.
The Moon is too far from the Sun.
The Moon doesn’t have a magnetic field.

questions.question: What does the principle of conservation of energy state?
options: Energy can be created and destroyed.
Energy is always transferred from one object to another.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed.
Energy is only found in moving objects.

questions.question: What is the difference between an elastic collision and an inelastic collision?
options: In an elastic collision, energy is conserved, but momentum is not.
In an elastic collision, momentum is conserved, but energy is not.
In an inelastic collision, both momentum and energy are conserved.
In an elastic collision, both momentum and energy are conserved.

questions.question: What does the term 'black body' refer to in physics?
options: An object that absorbs all radiation and reflects none.
An object that emits only infrared radiation.
An object that reflects all radiation.
An object that absorbs and reflects an equal amount of radiation.

questions.question: Why do objects appear to be different colors?
options: They emit light at different wavelengths.
They absorb light of certain wavelengths and reflect others.
They change the frequency of the light passing through them.
They reflect all wavelengths equally.

questions.question: Which type of energy does a stretched spring possess?
options: Kinetic energy.
Gravitational potential energy.
Elastic potential energy.
Chemical energy.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a fuse in an electrical circuit?
options: To increase the resistance and protect the circuit.
To decrease the resistance and increase current.
To break the circuit if the current is too high.
To convert electrical energy into heat.

questions.question: What does an electromagnet rely on to create a magnetic field?
options: A moving electric charge.
A stationary electric charge.
A changing electric field.
A changing gravitational field.

questions.question: What happens when a wave moves from one medium to another?
options: The speed and wavelength change, but the frequency remains constant.
The frequency changes, but the speed and wavelength remain constant.
The speed and frequency remain constant, but the wavelength changes.
The wavelength changes, but the frequency remains constant.
